chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Contraindications and cautions

  • Avoid the use of topical brimonidine in people who:
    • Have cerebral insufficiency.
    • Have coronary insufficiency or severe cardiovascular disease.
    • Have depression.
    • Have postural hypotension.
    • Have Raynaud's syndrome.
    • Have thromboangiitis obliterans.
    • Have hepatic or renal impairment.
    • Are pregnant or breastfeeding — manufacturer advises to avoid, but limited information available.
  • Avoid contact of brimonidine gel with the eyes, mouth, mucous membranes. Avoid application to irritated or damaged skin to minimize the risk of systemic absorption.
  • Apply other topical preparations (including cosmetics) only after brimonidine gel has dried on the skin.

Adverse effects

  • Possible adverse effects of topical brimonidine include:
    • Dizziness, dry mouth, headache, skin reactions, flushing (common).
    • Angio-oedema, eyelid oedema, nasal congestion, paraesthesia, cold peripheries (uncommon).
    • Systemic cardiovascular effects, such as dizziness (common), hypotension, bradycardia (rare).
    • Possible exacerbation of rosacea symptoms (common) — treatment should be initiated with a small amount of gel (less than the maximum dose) for at least 1 week, then increased gradually, based on tolerability and response. The maximum daily dose (1 g of gel per day) should not be exceeded, and the person should stop treatment and seek medical advice if symptoms worsen during treatment.

Drug interactions

  • There are no reported major drug interactions with topical brimonidine.

[MHRA, 2016; MHRA, 2017; Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]

subChapters.htmlHeader: Ivermectin
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Contraindications and cautions

  • Prescribe topical ivermectin with caution to people:
    • With severe hepatic impairment.
    • Who are pregnant or breastfeeding — manufacturer advises to avoid, but limited information available.

Adverse effects

  • Common possible adverse effects are skin reactions.

Drug interactions

  • As systemic absorption can follow topical application, there is a potential risk that topical ivermectin can increase the anticoagulant effect of warfarin.

[Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]

Contraindications and cautions

  • Avoid contact of topical azelaic acid with the eyes, mouth, and mucous membranes.

Adverse effects

  • Possible adverse effects of topical azelaic acid include:
    • Skin reactions (uncommon).
    • Exacerbation of asthma (rare).
    • Cheilitis (rare).

Drug interactions

  • There are no reported drug interactions with topical azelaic acid.

[Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]

Contraindications and cautions

  • Avoid exposure to strong sunlight or ultraviolet light with topical use.
  • Avoid contact with the eyes, mouth, and mucous membranes.

Adverse effects

  • Common possible adverse effects are skin reactions.
  • Severe bullous skin reactions, such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), or acute generalised exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP), have been reported. If symptoms/signs are present, treatment must be immediately discontinued.

Drug interactions

  • As systemic absorption can follow topical application, there is a potential risk that topical metronidazole may:
    • Increase the concentration of lithium.
    • Increase the anticoagulant effect of warfarin.

[Joint Formulary Committee, 2020]
